standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.

question.content: **Choose the number line that represents the equation, $\dfrac15+\dfrac15+\dfrac15+\dfrac15=\dfrac45$.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fifth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark, then moves right one tick mark, then moves right one tick mark, and then moves right one tick mark, ending at the fourth tick mark to the right of 0.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-sixth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark, then right one tick mark, then right one tick mark, and then right one tick mark, ending at the fourth tick mark to the right of 0.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-sixth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark, then right one tick mark, then right one tick mark, then right one tick mark, and then right one tick mark, ending at the fifth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: The equation uses fifths. So we need a number line where each whole is divided into $5$ equal parts.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fifth unit marked. Above the number line is a fraction bar of equal length. The fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts each labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: In the equation, we add $\dfrac15+\dfrac15+\dfrac15+\dfrac15$. So we need to move $\dfrac15$ four times.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fifth unit marked. Above the number line, an arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark representing one-fifth, then right one tick mark representing one-fifth, then right one tick mark representing one-fifth, and then right one tick mark representing one fifth, ending at the four tick mark to the right of 0. Together the four jumps of the arrow are labeled one-fifth plus one-fifth plus one-fifth plus one-fifth. Below the number line, another arrow begins at zero and moves right four ticks marks representing four-fifths, ending on the fourth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: This number line represents the equation:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fifth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark, then moves right one tick mark, then moves right one tick mark, and then moves right one tick mark, ending at the fourth tick mark to the right of 0.

question.content: **Choose the number line that represents the equation, $\dfrac48+\dfrac18+\dfrac28=\dfrac78$.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-eighth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 4 tick marks, then moves right 2 tick marks, then moves right 1 tick mark, ending at the seventh tick mark to the right of 0.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-tenth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 4 tick marks, then moves right 2 tick marks, then moves right 1 tick mark, ending at the seventh tick mark to the right of 0.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-eighth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 3 tick marks, then moves right 2 tick marks, then moves right 1 tick mark, ending at the sixth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: The equation uses eighths. So we need a number line where each whole is divided into $8$ equal parts.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-eighth unit marked. Above the number line is a fraction bar of equal length. The fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts each labeled one-eighth.

hints.content: In the equation, we add $\dfrac48+\dfrac18+\dfrac28$.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-eighth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 4 tick marks representing four-eighths, then moves right 2 tick marks representing two-eighths, then moves right 1 tick mark representing one-eighth, ending at the seventh tick mark to the right of 0. Together the three jumps of the arrow are labeled four-eighths plus two-eighths plus one-eighth.  Below the number line another arrow begins and 0 and moves right 7 tick marks, representing seven-eighths, ending at the seventh tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: This number line represents the equation:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-eighth unit marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 4 tick marks, then moves right 2 tick marks, then moves right 1 tick mark, ending at the seventh tick mark to the right of 0.

question.content: **Choose the number line that represents the equation, $\dfrac26+\dfrac36+\dfrac26=\dfrac76$.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-sixth unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right two tick marks, then moves right three tick marks, then moves right two tick marks, ending at the first tick mark to the right of 1.

A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-eighth unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right two tick marks, then moves right three tick marks, then moves right two tick marks, ending at the seventh tick mark to the right of 0.

A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-fourth unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right two tick marks, then moves right three tick marks, them moves right two tick marks, ending at the third tick mark to the right of 1.

hints.content: The equation uses sixths. So we need a number line where each whole is divided into $6$ equal parts.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line 0 to 2 with tick marks labeled at 0, 1, and 2. Tick marks at every one-sixth unit are marked. Above the number line is a fraction bar of equal length. The fraction bar is divided into 12 equal parts each labeled one-sixth. The first 6 parts of the fraction bar above 0 to 1 on the number line are offset together. The second 6 parts of the fraction bar are above 1 to 2 on the number line.

hints.content: In the equation, we add $\dfrac26+\dfrac36+\dfrac26$.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-sixth unit are marked. Above the number line, an arrow begins at 0 and moves right two tick marks representing two-sixths, then moves right three tick marks representing three-sixths, then moves right two tick mark representing two-sixths, ending at the first tick mark to the right of 1. Together the three jumps of the arrow are labeled two-sixths plus three-sixths plus two-sixths. Below the number line, another arrow begins at zero and moves right seven tick marks representing seven-sixths, ending at the first tick mark to the right of 1.

hints.content: This number line represents the equation:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-sixth unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right two tick marks, then moves right three tick marks, then moves right two tick marks, ending at the first tick mark to the right of 1.

question.content: Each tape diagram represents $1$ whole.  **Choose the tape diagram that represents the equation, $\dfrac18+\dfrac28+\dfrac28=\dfrac58$.**

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 8 equal parts.  The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together, the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

A tape diagram divided into 9 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together, the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

hints.content: The equation uses eighths. So we need a tape diagram with $8$ equal parts.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled one-eighth.

hints.content: In the equation, we add $\dfrac{1}{8}$, $\dfrac{2}{8}$, and $\dfrac{2}{8}$. So we need groups of $1$ eighth, $2$ eighths, and another $2$ eighths.    [[☃ image 1]]  Altogether, the groups show $5$ eighths.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 8 equal parts.  The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled one-eight. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled two-eighths. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-eighths. Together, the curved brackets above the tape diagram are labeled one-eighth plus two-eighths plus two-eighths. A curved bracket below the shaded parts of the tape diagram is labeled five-eighths.

hints.content: This tape diagram represents the equation:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 8 equal parts.  The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

question.content: Each tape diagram represents $1$ whole.  **Choose the tape diagram that represents the equation, $\dfrac{2}{10}+\dfrac3{10}+\dfrac{1}{10}=\dfrac6{10}$.**

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 10 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The third, fourth, and fifth parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The sixth part is labeled green with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded part is labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

A tape diagram divided into 12 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The third, fourth, and fifth parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The sixth part is labeled green with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded part is labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

A tape diagram divided into 8 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The third, fourth, and fifth parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The sixth part is labeled green with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded part is labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

hints.content: The equation uses tenths. So we need a tape diagram with $10$ equal parts.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 10 equal parts. Each part is labeled one-tenth.

hints.content: In the equation, we add $\dfrac{2}{10}$, $\dfrac{3}{10}$, and $\dfrac{1}{10}$. So we need groups of $2$ tenths, $3$ tenths, and another $1$ tenth.    [[☃ image 1]]  Altogether, the groups show $6$ tenths.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 10 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled two-tenths. The third, fourth, and fifth parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled three-tenths. The sixth part is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-tenth. Together, the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled two-tenths plus three-tenths plus one-tenth. A curved bracket below the shaded parts is labeled six-tenths.

hints.content: This tape diagram represents the equation:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 10 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The third, fourth, and fifth parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The sixth part is labeled green with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded part is labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

question.content: Each tape diagram represents $1$ whole.  **Choose the tape diagram that represents the equation, $\dfrac{1}{4}+\dfrac2{4}=\dfrac3{4}$.**

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark.

A tape diagram divided into 8 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fourth, fifth, and sixth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark.

hints.content: The equation uses fourths. So we need a tape diagram with $4$ equal parts.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled one-fourth.

hints.content: In the equation, we add $\dfrac{1}{4}$ and $\dfrac{2}{4}$. So we need groups of $1$ fourth and $2$ fourths.   [[☃ image 1]]  Altogether, the groups show $3$ fourths.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled one-fourth. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled two-fourths. Together, the curved brackets above the tape diagram is labeled one-fourth plus two-fourths. A curved bracket below the shaded parts of the tape diagram is labeled three-fourths.

hints.content: This tape diagram represents the equation:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together, the curved brackets above the tape diagram are labeled question mark plus question mark.

question.content: **Choose the equation represented by the following number line.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks every one-fourth unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 1 tick mark, then moves right 3 tick marks, and then moves right 2 tick marks, ending two tick marks to the right of 1.

hints.content: There are $4$ equal parts in $1$ whole, so each segment is equal to $\dfrac14$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line 0 to 2 with tick marks labeled at 0, 1, and 2. Tick marks at every one-fourth unit are marked. Above the number line is a fraction bar of equal length. The fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts each labeled one-fourth. The first 4 parts of the fraction bar above 0 to 1 on the number line are offset together. The second 4 parts of the fraction bar are above 1 to 2 on the number line.

hints.content: Each segment is $\dfrac14$, so we can count the number of segments to find the size of each jump .   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks every one-fourth unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right 1 tick mark representing one-fourth, then moves right 3 tick marks representing three-fourths, and then moves right 2 tick marks representing two-fourths, ending two tick marks to the right of 1. Together the three jumps of the arrow are labeled one-fourth plus three-fourths plus two-fourths. Below the number line, an arrow begins at 0 and moves right 6 tick marks representing six-fourths, ending two tick marks to the right of 1.

hints.content: The equation represented by the number line is $\dfrac14+\dfrac34+\dfrac24=\dfrac64$.

question.content: **Choose the equation represented by the following number line.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks at every one-tenth unit marked. An arrow beings at 0 and moves right three tick marks, then moves right three tick marks, and then moves right two tick marks, ending at the eighth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: There are $10$ equal parts in $1$ whole, so each segment is equal to $\dfrac1{10}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-tenth unit marked. Above the number line is a fraction bar of equal length. The fraction bar is divided into 10 equal parts each labeled one-tenth.

hints.content: Each segment is $\dfrac1{10}$, so we can count the number of segments to find the size of each jump .    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-tenth unit marked. Above the number line, an arrow begins at 0 and moves right three tick marks representing three-tenths, then moves right three tick marks representing three-tenths, then moves right two tick marks representing two-tenths, ending at the eighth tick mark to the right of 0. Together the three jumps of the arrow are labeled three-tenths plus three-tenths plus two-tenths. Below the number line, another arrow begins at zero and moves right eight ticks marks representing eight-tenths, ending on the eighth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: The equation represented by the number line is $\dfrac3{10}+\dfrac3{10}+\dfrac2{10} = \dfrac8{10}$.

question.content: **Choose the equation represented by the following number line.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-third unit are marked. An arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark, then moves right three tick marks, then moves right one tick mark, ending at the fifth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: There are $3$ equal parts in $1$ whole, so each segment is equal to $\dfrac1{3}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line 0 to 2 with tick marks labeled at 0, 1, and 2. Tick marks at every one-third unit are marked. Above the number line is a fraction bar of equal length. The fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts each labeled one-third. The first 3 parts of the fraction bar above 0 to 1 on the number line are offset together. The second 3 parts of the fraction bar are above 1 to 2 on the number line.

hints.content: Each segment is $\dfrac1{3}$, so we can count the number of segments to find the size of each jump .  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 emphasized. Tick marks at every one-third unit are marked. Above the number line, an arrow begins at 0 and moves right one tick mark representing one-third, then moves right three tick marks representing three-thirds, then moves right one tick mark representing one-third, ending at the fifth tick mark to the right of 0. Together the three jumps of the arrow are labeled one third plus three-thirds plus one-third. Below the number line, another arrow begins at zero and moves right five tick marks representing five-thirds, ending at the fifth tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: The equation represented by the number line is $\dfrac1{3}+\dfrac3{3}+\dfrac1{3} = \dfrac5{3}$.

question.content: **Choose the equation represented by the following tape diagram.**   *The entire tape diagram represents $1$ whole.*

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled question mark. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

hints.content: There are $6$ equal parts in the whole, so each segment is $\dfrac16$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. Each part is labeled one-sixth.

hints.content: The diagram shows segments that are equal to $\dfrac16 + \dfrac26 + \dfrac26$.   [[☃ image 1]]    Altogether, the groups show $\dfrac56$.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. The first part is shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled one-sixth. The second and third parts are shaded pink with a curved bracket above them labeled two-sixths. The fourth and fifth parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-sixths. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled one-sixth plus two-sixths plus two-sixths. A curved bracket below the shaded parts of the tape diagram is labeled five-sixths.

hints.content: The equation represented by the tape diagram is $\dfrac16+\dfrac26 + \dfrac26=\dfrac56$.

question.content: **Choose the equation represented by the following tape diagram.**   *The entire tape diagram represents $1$ whole.*

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket labeled question mark above them. The third part is shaded pink with a curved bracket labeled question mark above it. The fourth part is shaded green with a curved bracket labeled question mark above it. Together the curved brackets above the shaded parts are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

hints.content: There are $5$ equal parts in the whole, so each segment is $\dfrac15$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. Each part is labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: The diagram shows segments that are equal to $\dfrac25 + \dfrac15 + \dfrac15$.   [[☃ image 1]]    Altogether, the groups show $\dfrac45$.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. The first and second parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled two-fifths. The third part is shaded pink with a curved bracket above it labeled one-fifth. The fourth part is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-fifth. Together, the curved brackets above the tape diagram is labeled two-fifths plus one-fifth plus one-fifth. A curved bracket below the shaded parts of the tape diagram is labeled four-fifths.

hints.content: The equation represented by the tape diagram is $\dfrac25+\dfrac15 + \dfrac15=\dfrac45$.

question.content: **Choose the equation represented by the following tape diagram.**   *The entire tape diagram represents $1$ whole.*

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 12 equal segments. The first 4 segments are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. The fifth segment is shaded pink and labeled question mark. Segments 6 through 10 are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled question mark. Together the curved brackets above the tape diagram are labeled question mark plus question mark plus question mark.

hints.content: There are $12$ equal parts in the whole, so each segment is $\dfrac1{12}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into twelve equal segments. Each segment is labeled one twelfth.

hints.content: The diagram shows segments that are equal to $\dfrac4{12} + \dfrac1{12} + \dfrac5{12}$.  [[☃ image 1]]    Altogether, the groups show $\dfrac{10}{12}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into twelve equal segments. The first four segments are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-twelfths. The fifth segment is shaded pink and labeled one-twelfth. Segments 6 through 10 are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled five-twelfths. Together the curved brackets above the tape diagram is labeled four-twelfths plus one-twelfth plus five-twelfths. A curved bracket below segments 1 through 10 of the tape diagram is labeled ten-twelfths.

hints.content: The equation represented by the tape diagram is $\dfrac4{12}+\dfrac1{12} + \dfrac5{12}=\dfrac{10}{12}$.
